Americans used to be world leaders in all almost fields of technology, and we had a huge thriving aerospace industry constantly innovating.  Now we have just a shadow of that, and most of our tech "innovation" is focused on smart phone apps.

We need to flex our tech muscles, expand our horizons, and revitalize dying industries and research or we'll end up watching the Chinese dominate the world while we sit around playing Call of Duty.

And we achieve  this by orbiting the moon for nth time? How is that flexing our muscle? Building a rocket that does what's already been done? China and Russia will quake when this milestone is achieved.

We had to do a major reset in the space program.  We lost a lot of ground being distracted by the Space Shuttle program, which seemed like the next step in the '70s but ultimately proved too ambitious.  It was a massive budgetary sink-hole and failed miserably at it's primary goals -- to make space launches cheap, frequent and safe.  

Once we got rid of that we went back to where we left off in 1973 -- conventional single-use rockets and apollo-style capsules and landers.  It's only an incremental improvement over Apollo, but we have to relearn how we did it before so we can advance further.  Keep in mind all the people who designed and built Apollo are long gone.  

But the current Artemis system approach is evolving and by the end of this decade few people expect we'll still be using the single use SLS rocket and Apollo-style capsules. We have learned not to bite off too much too soon, but we're still trying to keep ahead of the Chinese.

We're going to the Moon again mainly because the Chinese have announced plans to go there and set up a permanent base.  They could theoretically get there by the end of the decade.  

Aside from the embarrassment of us being stuck on Earth looking at a Chinese Moon with no way to get there, there are actual strategic reasons to get there first -- the Moon is a source of He3, potentially useful as a clean nuclear fuel, and the best place to set up a base for lunar exploration is at the lunar south pole, where suitable landing sites occupy only a couple of square miles.  If the Chinese occupy those sites first we will be relegated to "second choice" base locations.

replies.context: The space visionaries of the '60s never intended lunar exploration to be a "one and done" event.  Exploring, and exploiting the Moon was supposed to be an ongoing process.  We're just proceeding from where they left off in 1972.

That was just an initial exploration - mostly a political space race with Russia. This time we're going with the intent of establishing a permanently manned base on the moon, to work on creating our own water, oxygen, rocket fuel, building materials, etc. from the moon's materials. It's a test run for a Mars base plus would be a much more economical launch point to Mars if we can make most of our Mars supplies on the moon - since the moon has only 1/6th the gravity of Earth.

A LOT of incompetent fools in the comments questioning "why SpaceX isn't designing and paying for this launch". BECAUSE THEY CAN'T. This rocket may look similar to the Apollo Program rockets but it is infinitely more powerful and complex. The engineering decision was made to have the Human Capsule land via parachutes in the ocean with a recovery ship nearby because quite simply, IT'S THE SAFEST WAY TO LAND ASTRONAUTS. While this may not be the sexiest way to accomplish this, it has been proven to be, from an engineering standpoint, the most repeatably stable and cost-effective system. This ain't StarTek, it's real life. 
SpaceX, which has had obvious success launch small to midsize, unmanned rockets and LOW EARTH ORBIT MANNED CAPSULES is not ready to safely launch humans this far out into space.
I'd really like to understand what the perceived benefit is of orbiting the moon or landing on its surface. It sounds to me like another government waste of money.
